{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2981921,"name":"Louie Joshua Labata","username":"LJ109","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-16T07:22:47.824Z","cooked":"

I am a senior looking to utilize VSCode’s Robot Simulator to test my project’s logic before deploying and running it on the actual robot. I have a limited small amount of programming knowledge and so, I have been learning through watching YouTube tutorials. One such tutorial is made by Nevin Morrison, titled “FRC - Command Base System - Java - VS Code 2020.”

I want to understand how to program using the Command Based Structure but I have hit a wall when using the VSCode Robot Simulator. In Part 4 of the tutorial…

This window of the Simulator is not an option for me to view, it is greyed out. This is preventing me from following along with the tutorial in regards to using the Robot Simulator. For example, I cannot see the PWM Output of these objects so I am lost on how to use the simulator in order to check if I have properly programmed my motor controllers. I cannot tell if when I press a button on my controller the motor controller is responding correctly by spinning outputting a number on the PWM.

For your information, I am programming using WPI_TalonSRX classes/encoders.

My ultimate question is, “Are there other resources that can help me understand how to either: A) fix this problem, or B) Understand how to use the Robot Simulator well enough that I can find another solution.” Thank you so much for your time!

The tutorial assumes use of PWM based motor controllers. WPI_TalonSRX motor controllers are CAN devices and thus will not show up under the PWM outputs window. You should see information for each TalonSRX under the Other Devices window.

Thank you for replying! I figured out that my problem was not only my limited understanding of how the TalonSRX would be displayed in the Other Devices window. It was also the fact that I had accidentally only ran part of my code instead of the entire thing. There was a stop somewhere that meant the code stopped at a specific line which meant it only ran the program as if I had coded just a Drive Train subsystem.
